results.title: Get heelers they said it will be fun they said...
results.material_description: Digital screen recording from @sandrastevenjenkins20's Tiktok feed
results.brief_description: Covid Lockdowns prompted many people to get a puppy - but not everyone was ready for the energy bomb of a heeler in their life! This is one of countless social media videos showing footage of heeler puppies chewing, biting, fighting and wriggling their way into the lives of their new humans.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Covid-19 lockdowns prompted many people to get a puppy – but not everyone was ready for the energy bomb of a heeler in their life! This viral video uses the phrasal meme template “X, they said”, which allows people to substitute the X (in this case, heeler puppies) with whatever supposedly fun or simple situation happens to backfire on them. As Know Your Meme outlines, this meme template originated in Warcraft 2 with footmen who would say, “‘Join the army!’, they said. ‘See the world!’, they said… I’d rather be sailing.”
description_for_label:
This responsive display presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Covid-19 lockdowns prompted many people to get a puppy – but not everyone was ready for the energy bomb of a heeler in their life! This viral video uses a phrasal meme template “X, they said”, which allows people to substitute the X (in this case, heeler puppies) with whatever supposedly fun and simple situation that happens to backfire on them. It originated in Warcraft 2 with footmen who would say, “‘Join the army!’, they said. ‘See the world!’, they said… I’d rather be sailing.”

results.title: Ariarne Titmus’ coach Dean Boxall on her winning gold
results.brief_description: Australians were in a frenzy of excitement when Ariarne Titmus won gold in the women’s 400m freestyle in her Olympic debut in Tokyo. Managing to dethrone previous Olympic medallist Katie Ledecky, Titmus later spoke of the pain and years of dedication it took to win. Knowing her journey full well, no one else was more ecstatic than her coach, Dean Boxell.
results.title_for_label: Ariarne Titmus’ coach Dean Boxall on her winning gold
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Australians were in a frenzy of excitement when Ariarne Titmus won gold in the women’s 400m freestyle in her Olympic debut in Tokyo. After dethroning defending champion Katie Ledecky, Titmus revealed the years of dedication it took to win, telling Sunrise: “Physically, it’s a lot of training. On the days that I’m at the pool twice a day I could be there up to seven or eight hours and Dean is there a lot longer.”

Knowing her journey full well, no one else was more ecstatic than her coach, Dean Boxell, whose enthusiastic celebration was thrust into the limelight across social media.

Boxell was captured enthusiastically dancing, punching the air, screaming in joy, and yes, air-humping the glass barrier in celebration. His vigorous outpouring almost immediately went viral, spreading across local news, Twitter and Instagram after countless Olympic viewers filmed their TV screens and shared it online. Many were right there with him, finding his gut reaction honest, endearing and typically Australian.

But others found the display over the top and offensive, leading to a backlash from some Twitter users, especially Americans. Was this something that only Australian audiences could understand? Or was this an example of inflated male privilege? Titmus certainly didn’t mind at all and was thrilled to share the moment with her fervently loyal coach, who was inspired by his favourite wrestler from childhood, Ultimate Warrior.

“He is my favourite. I used to wrestle with my brother … I loved the Ultimate Warrior,” he has said.
description_for_label:
This responsive display presents the moment, stories ad memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Australians were in a frenzy of excitement when Ariarne Titmus won gold in the women’s 400m freestyle in her Olympic debut in Tokyo. After dethroning defending champion Katie Ledecky, Titmus revealed the years of dedication it took to win. Knowing her journey full well, no one was more excited than coach Dean Boxell, whose celebration was thrust into the limelight across social media.

results.title: Mozart's House
results.creator_credit: Jack Patterson, Clean Film and Channel 4
results.brief_description: Made during Moscow’s biggest ever heat wave when the smog was thick and Red Square was actually red. The song was sung very slowly, the footage was then sped up to reflect the high energy vocals and the synths lines that sound almost randomised.
results.description: Made during Moscow’s biggest ever heat wave when the smog was thick and Red Square was actually red. The song was sung very slowly, the footage was then sped up to reflect the high energy vocals and the synths lines that sound almost randomised.

results.title: My City
results.creator_credit: Robert Ryan, Deuce Films and Channel 4
results.brief_description: The film highlights a part of London that is often forgotten; the gap between the rich and poor, street crime, the rich melting pot of cultures, rundown urban spaces and how expensive it is to really enjoy our capital…

results.title: Light Percussion

results.title: Chaps on Tour 2011 [Short version]
results.brief_description: A specially made abridged version of the amazing ‘Chaps On Tour’ film, made by Toby Segar - at the age of just 16. Toby and his six friends set out to capture an image of their lives: fun and friendship driven by their mutual love of Parkour.

results.title: Polybius
results.creator_credit: James Houston, Joanne Daly, Bold Yin and Channel 4
results.brief_description: A SEGA Mega Drive, Commodore 64, floppy disk drives and hard drives sing in unison. The unusual ensemble (controlled live via MIDI) is given a last curtain call in a nostalgic farewell to forgotten friends.

results.title: We are the People
results.brief_description: The choir brings together Akala, PGR, Beardyman, Wretch 32, Ms Dynamite and Lady Leshurr with members of the YouTube community who uploaded performances to the YouTube channel. Together they perform an original track made by the human voice.
